meaning: A figure of speech comparing two unlike things without using like or as.
Visually descriptive language.
The person who tells a story.
Conversation between two or more characters.
A grouped set of lines in a poem.
The time and place of a story.
To indicate or hint at a future event.
A reference to another work or idea.
A struggle between opposing forces.
Exaggerated statements not meant to be taken literally.
A person or being in a story.
The main sequence of events in a narrative.
A section at the end of a book or play that serves as a conclusion.
A category of artistic composition.
An opening section of a literary work.
A previous statement from which another is inferred.
A simple story used to illustrate a moral lesson.
A brief summary of something.
A secondary or subordinate plot.
A nineteen-line poetic form with two refrains.
A story that can be interpreted to reveal a hidden meaning.
A character who opposes the protagonist.
A very typical example of a certain person or thing.
Emotional release through art.
The final part of a play where matters are resolved.
Place side by side for contrast.
A recurring element in a literary work.
A long speech by one actor.
A word formed to imitate a sound.
A word blending sounds and combining meanings.
The medieval curriculum of arithmetic, geometry, music, and astronomy.
Extravagantly enthusiastic; ecstatic.
Use of symbols to represent ideas.
A figure of speech in which a part represents the whole.
A piece of thick textile fabric with designs.

Appearing to be true or real.
The defining spirit or mood of a period.
Plural of ellipsis (omission of words).
Relating to an elegy; expressing sorrow.
A novel about the formative years of the main character.
Relationship between texts, especially literary ones.
Fiction that self-consciously addresses the devices of fiction.
The point in a play when a principal character recognizes a truth.
A sudden breaking off in speech.
A figure of speech in which an abstract thing is personified.
Figure of speech in which a word refers to a thing indirectly through multiple steps of meaning.
Theory and methodology of interpretation, especially scripture.
The action of being turned inside out or folded back on itself.
Relating to something reused or altered but still bearing visible traces of its earlier form.
The process of being addressed into social categories.
Excessively flattering toward a subject of biography.
A sentence that lacks grammatical sequence.
Relating to a figure of speech applying a word to multiple parts.
Presence of multiple voices or styles in a text.
